data.title: Impressive History
data.text: This is one of 5 structures left standing following Sherman's Mach to the Sea and the burning of Atlanta.   It still is an active Catholic site.   It is impressive, has been well maintained and served as a downtown anchor near the Georgia Capitol.  As with all major cities, please remember to be vigilant!

data.title: Beautiful church
data.text: While visiting Atlanta for a weekend I stopped in here for Sunday mass and was warmly greeted. This historic church is very beautiful and well worth a visit.

data.title: A "Peace" of History
data.text: Founded by an Irish Priest in 1848, that used the sanctuary as a hospital to treat both northern and southern soldiers during the Civil War, in the years since it has retained a spirit of peace, recognizing we are all brothers and sisters in Christ. A wonderful place to visit. A wonderful place to worship.

data.title: Don't Walk By Without Visiting
data.text: Having lived in Atlanta most of my life, I am surprised I never visited this beautiful shrine until now. The rich history, the stunning architecture, and the detailed stained glass features make this a true treasure of our city.

data.title: Very spiritual church.
data.text: The church has daily mass at 12:10 Monday to Friday and a morning mass on Saturday usually around 9:15.  Sunday masses are 8:30 and 11:00 am.  Other than those times the sanctuary is locked.

data.title: Wonderful church and super nice attendant
data.text: It was wonderful to see this church.   We were allowed to walk around as we pleased.   There are some people who appear to be "undesirables" on the porch steps...BUT.....they were some of  the nicest people we had ever met so don't judge.  One even showed us how to get to the side door to be let in and told us to have a great day.   The front doors are locked during the day but if you go to the side door and push the buzzer they will gladly let you in.

data.title: There's always a Catholic Church anywhere in the world
data.text: I was on a business trip to Atlanta on December 8, a holiday of obligation for catholics. I Googled the place and found the Shrine of the Immaculate Conception a walking distance from our hotel.

data.title: Sacred History
data.text:
Very much welcomed after ringing the doorbell.  They keep the doors locked for some very obvious looking reasons on the street but you are very much welcomed.  We were told all about the inside of the church and then left to browse as we saw fit.  The church endured a fire and much of the interior has been rebuilt.
One of only three historic churches in the downtown area left and worth visiting for church architecture and history.

data.title: A Beautiful Cathedral
data.text: The Rose Window is worth it to go see all by itself. The cathedral is storied, predating the Civil War and rebuilt afterwards due to the damage sustained during the shelling. This is the oldest Catholic Parish in Atlanta and the church is well worth visiting.

data.title: Beautiful
data.text: I love old churches and this place was wonderful. beautiful sanctuary with a classic look. wonderful for photos. I must say, I enjoyed this beautiful church.

data.title: culture place to visit
data.text: Its nice, for culture, I´ve meet a guy in that place who explained me more about the story of that place and was useful, if you can find someone there will be better than visit by yourself

data.title: First time visit. Will be back!
data.text: Absolutely beautiful church! The ceiling has the apostles hand painted. The altar is breathtaking and the stained glass windows are beautiful.

data.title: Beautiful Church
data.text: Beautiful old church, went to my nieces wedding here, parking is at a minimum. Park at the Underground entrance.

data.title: Interesting Historically
data.text: Great story attached to this church.  Apparently when Sherman took Atlanta, and ordered the city to be burned, a priest, Fr. O'Reilly, influenced Sherman not to burn the church by telling him Union soldiers would desert if ordered to destroy the church.  Apparently, some soldiers protected the church; in addition, a couple of other churches were also spared and Atlanta's city hall. Fr. O'Reilly is buried here.  I definitely felt a sense of history when visiting this site.

data.title: Couldn't get inside.
data.text: This church had some interesting plaques outside to read about this history but that's about all we could do. The doors were locked. It was only the way to the Capitol building so we stopped and read. Children would not appreciate it.

data.title: A warm Parish
data.text: Attended services here several times. The parishioners are pretty warm. or me, the service was a bit flat. Its not an especially beautiful church, by Catholic standards. Pretty standard mass experience all in all.

data.title: A beautiful Franciscan Church in the shadow of the capitol
data.text: This is a beautiful Catholic Church with a unique past entrenched in the Siege of Atlanta and Gen. Sherman's famous march to the sea where he burned everything to the ground.  When the church had a major fire in the 1900's taking the roof with it, Atlantas rose up to support the refurbishing of this historic church. In the renovation that followed a forgotten and then closed off crept was  discovered containing the remains of two priests, one being Fr. O'Reilly who is credited interceding with General Sherman as he burned much of Atlanta to save not only the Catholic Church but also several other prominent Christian churches. These remaining churches would provide sanctuary to the returning Atlantans after the Union troops moved on to Savannah, burning a 60 mile wide path to the sea. So whether your Catholic, a Civil War buff or a lover of church art and statuary, this is good 30-60 minute side trip worth the visit. Drop by around service times, as the church is locked. Check their website for exact times and a nice history of the church and explanation of the art.

data.title: The 1st Catholic Church in Atlanta !
data.text: A must for Catholics and history lovers alike.  The first Catholic Church built in Atlanta, back when it was called Terminus ( Walking Dead lovers delight !).  The building is beautifully designed with a red brick façade.  Inside the high ceiling is painted in portraits of many Saints.  The nave features a high altar, evoking the pre-Vatican II counsel era.  Definitely worth a stop in if you're in the area.  The day I visited a very busy soup kitchen was serving the needy waiting outside.

data.title: Beautiful interior
data.text: I enjoy taking photographs of places of worship throughout the United States. So, I hoped to capture some photos of this historic structure. When I arrived, the front doors were locked. I was able to enter a side door. I was permitted to enter the church and allowed to take photographs for over an hour. They even turned all the chandeliers on to make the scene more photogenic. The people I met were very friendly and accommodating. I was also pleased to see that several homeless people were being fed by church personnel during my visit. I'm very glad that I stopped by.

data.title: Beauty of Simplicity and History
data.text:
Catholic Shrine of the Immaculate Conception is the paragon of simple beauty. The church may lack the grandeur and the scale of a Catholic cathedral, but the Shrine nonetheless does not shy in serenity and majesty. Whether you are a Catholic or not, this historical church should be on your list of attractions to visit especially if you are in the Downtown area and enjoys history.

Located near the Georgia State Capitol and almost next door to the Central Presbyterian Church, the Catholic Shrine is one of the oldest churches in Georgia that was fortunate to survive the scathe of the Civil War (Or "The War Between the States" according to a nearby plaque). 

The main church has only one large interior room, but within this room, you will find the sides flanked with gorgeous stained glass windows and paintings describing the Passion of Christ. The ceiling is adorned with eight large colorful portraits of Catholic saints. However, the main spotlight as you walked in the building is the ornate main altar. Absorb the serene atmosphere as you slowly walk toward the main altar to admire its detailed beauty!

If you are only visiting like me, this Shrine will take less than one hour, so why not visit this beautiful church if you are already nearby?
